case_name: The Printers Mysore Private Ltd. v. Pothan Joseph

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1960 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 21, 1959, of the Mysore High Court, Bangalore, in Misc. Appeal No. 68 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 21, 1959 of Mysore High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 68 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 21, 1959, of the Mysore High Court, Bangalore, in Misc. Appeal No. 68 of 1959. Purshottam Prikamdas, S. N. Andley, J. B. DadaChanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent Pothan Joseph was working as Editor of Deccan Herald owned by appellant Printers Mysore Private Ltd in Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Pothan Joseph, who was working as the Editor of the Deccan Herald owned and published by the appellant, The Printers  Mysore  Private Ltd., in Bangalore has filed a suit against the appellant on two companytracts executed between the parties on April 1, 1948, and February 20, 1953, respectively,

facts.text: Two contracts executed between parties on April 1, 1948 and February 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and has claimed accounts of the working of the Deccan Herald newspaper from April 1, 1948, to March 31, 1958, as well as payment of the amount that may be found due to him from the appellant tinder the provisions of cls. 2 d  and 1 d  of the said companytracts.

facts.text: Suit claims accounts from April 1, 1948 to March 31, 1958 and payment due under clauses 2(d) and 1(d) of contracts.

anchor.surface_text: and has claimed accounts of the working of the Deccan Herald newspaper from April 1, 1948, to March 31, 1958, as well as payment of the amount that may be found due to him from the appellant tinder the provisions of cls. 2 d  and 1 d  of the said companytracts.

facts.text: Services of respondent terminated by appellant's letter dated September 28, 1957, effective from March 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The services of the respondent were terminated by the appellant by its letter dated September 28, 1957, in which the respondent was told that the termination would take effect from March 31, 1958.

facts.text: Subsequent letter on March 17, 1958 terminated services with immediate effect and asked to hand over to Mr. T. S. Ramachandra Rao.

anchor.surface_text: However, by a subsequent letter written by the appellant to the respondent on March 17, 1958, the respondent was told that his services had been terminated with immediate effect and he was asked to hand over charge to his successor, Mr. T. S. Ramachandra Rao.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit on July 14, 1958 against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on July 14, 1958, the respondent, filed the present suit against the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant contended contracts subject to arbitration agreement and applied under s.34 Arbitration Act to stay suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended that the two companytracts on which the respondents claim was based were subject to an arbitration agreement, and so it was number open to the respondent to file the present suit against the appellant.

facts.text: Trial judge refused to stay proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge who heard the appellants application, however, exercised his discretion against it and refused to stay the proceedings in the respondents suit.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Mysore High Court, appeal failed, High Court confirmed trial court order but for different reasons and transferred suit to Additional Civil Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant preferred an appeal in the Mysore High Court but his appeal failed and the High Court companyfirmed the order passed by the trial companyrt though for different reasons. The High Court, however, thought that the learned trial judge, in dealing with the appellants application bad gone much further than he should have done, and hence it was desirable that the case should be tried by some other judge .

facts.text: High Court rejected certificate under Art. 133(1) Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate. His application was, however, rejected on the ground that the decision under appeal companyld number be companysidered as a judgment, decree or final order under Art. 133 1  of the Constitution

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Then the appellant applied for and obtained special leave from this Court.

facts.text: Appellant is printing company owning Deccan Herald (English) and Prajavani (Kannada) at Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with the merits of the companytentions raised by the parties in this appeal it is necessary to set out briefly the relevant facts leading to the present litigation. The appellant is a printing companypany and it owns and publishes the Deccan Herald in English and Prajavani in Kannada at Bangalore.

facts.text: Contract dated April 1, 1948 engaged respondent as Editor for 5 years.

anchor.surface_text: By a companytract dated April 1, 1948, the appellant engaged the respondent as Editor of the Deccan Herald for a period of five years on terms and companyditions specified in the said companytract.

facts.text: Period extended by contract on February 20, 1953 for another 5 years per cl.5.

anchor.surface_text: As provided by el.  5  of the said companytract the period of the respondents employment was extended by another five years by a subsequent companytract entered into between the parties on February 20, 1953.

facts.text: Services terminated abruptly on March 17, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already mentioned the services of the respondent came to be terminated abruptly on March 17, 1958.

facts.text: Respondent by letter October 16, 1957 made claims under Working Journalists Act and 1/10th profits from 1948 to termination.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that by his letter dated October 16, 1957, the respondent made certain claims against the appellant under the provisions of the Working Journalists Act. Besides, he demanded 1/10th of the profits made by the Deccan Herald from 1948 up to the date of the termination of his service under the two respective companytracts.

facts.text: Appellant denied the claim.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was denied by the appellant.

facts.text: Contracts entitle respondent to 1/10th profits of Deccan Herald during employment.

anchor.surface_text: His case is that the two companytracts entitled him to claim 1/10th of the profits made by the Deccan Herald during the period of his employment,, and so he claims an account of the said profits and his due share in them.

facts.text: Supreme Court held dispute falls within arbitration agreement in para 4 of contract.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that the High Court was in error in companying to the companyclusion that the present dispute between the parties was outside the scope of paragraph 4 of the companytract.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal upholding discretion of courts below not to stay suit.

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances we do number think we would be justified in substituting our discretion for that of the companyrts below.

facts.text: Attempt to settle via mediation of Mr. Behram Doctor failed.

anchor.surface_text: He also held that an attempt was made by the parties to settle their differences amicably through the mediation of Mr. Behram Doctor but the said attempt failed because the appellant was number serious about it

facts.text: Respondent invoked arbitration on February 18, 1956 naming Mr. Behram Doctor.

anchor.surface_text: On February 18, 1956, the respondent invoked the arbitration agreement and told Mr. Venkataswamy that Mr. Behram Doctor had agreed to work as arbitrator and give his award  D. 2 .

facts.text: Meeting with Mr. Behram Doctor on May 9, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that subsequently Mr. Behrain Doctor met both the respondent and Mr. Venkataswamy on May 9, 1956.
under Art. 133 1  of the Constitution on that view it was thought unnecessary to decide whether on the merits the case was fit to be taken in appeal to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 of the Act companyfers power on the companyrt to stay legal proceedings where there is an arbitration agreement subject to the companyditions specified in the section. The companyditions thus specified are satisfied in the present case, but the section clearly companytemplates that, even though there is an arbitration agreement and the requisite companyditions specified by it are satisfied, the companyrt may nevertheless refuse to grant stay if it is satisfied that there are sufficient reasons why the matter should number be referred in accordance with the arbitration agreement.

concepts.interpretation: Must be exercised judicially according to common sense and justice; factors include party unwillingness, embittered relations, delay attributable to abandonment, fraud allegations, complex legal/constitutional issues

issues.text: whether the courts below were in error in refusing to stay the suit filed by the respondent against the appellant in view of the arbitration agreement between them

anchor.surface_text: Then the appellant applied for and obtained special leave from this Court. That is how this appeal has come before us and the substantial point which arises for our decision is whether the courts below were in error in refusing to stay the suit filed by the respondent against the appellant in view of the arbitration agreement between them.

issues.text: whether the present dispute between the parties was outside the scope of paragraph 4 of the contract
relates to the construction of the contracts between the parties

anchor.surface_text: The first point which calls for a decision relates to the construction of the contracts between the parties. As we have already stated two contracts were executed between them but their terms are substantially the same and so we may deal with the subsequent contract which was executed on February 20, 1953  P. 2 .

issues.text: whether or not the appellants complaint against the High Courts order can be upheld

anchor.surface_text: It is in the light of these principles that we must consider whether or not the appellants complaint against the High Courts order can be upheld. The first point which calls for a decision relates to the construction of the contracts between the parties.

issues.text: whether this Court should interfere with the concurrent exercise of discretion by the two courts below

anchor.surface_text: the matter has come to us under Art. 136, and so we can justly interfere with the concurrent exercise of the discretion by the courts below only if we feel that the said exercise of discretion is patently and manifestly unreasonable, capricious or perverse and that it may defeat the ends of justice.

arguments.claim: The two contracts are subject to an arbitration agreement, so the suit should be stayed under s.34 of the Arbitration Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that the two contracts on which the respondents claim was based were subject to an arbitration agreement, and so it was number open to the respondent to file the present suit against the appellant. The appellant, therefore, requested the Court under s. 34 of the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940,  hereinafter called the Act , to stay the proceedings initiated by the respondent and refer the dispute to arbitration in accordance with the arbitration agreement between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial judge found that the respective contentions raised by the parties before him showed that there was numberdispute as such between them which could attract the arbitration agreement.

arguments.court_reasoning: Dispute falls within para 4 of contract on proper construction

arguments.claim: Mediation attempt via Mr. Behram Doctor failed because appellant was not serious and sought to protract

anchor.surface_text: He also held that an attempt was made by the parties to settle their differences amicably through the mediation of Mr. Behram Doctor but the said attempt failed because the appellant was number serious about it

arguments.claim: Plea of limitation should be tried by court not arbitrators

anchor.surface_text: According to the learned trial judge a plea of limitation would fall to be considered in the present suit and it was desirable that the said plea should be tried by a competent court rather than by arbitrators.

arguments.claim: Accounts can be allocated by qualified accountant, little left for arbitrators; contract postulates separate accounts

anchor.surface_text: In dismissing the appellants claim for stay of the suit the learned judge observed that if the accounts of the Deccan Herald had number been separately maintained it would be competent for a qualified accountant to allocate expenses and capital expenses among the different activities of the appellant and then very little would be left for arbitrators to decide. He had nodoubt that the contract by which the respondent was entitled to claim 1/10th share in the profits of the Deccan Herald necessarily postulated that the accounts of the Deccan Herald would be separately maintained.

arguments.claim: Dispute does not fall within arbitration agreement as 'application of the contract' means dispute on applicability, not interpretation

anchor.surface_text: When the matter went in appeal the High Court held that the dispute between the parties did number fall within the arbitration agreement. The High Court also considered the other points decided by the trial court it held that Mr, Behram Doctor had number been appointed as an arbitrator between the parties and that the proceedings before him merely showed that the parties were exploring the possibility of having an arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 of the Act confers power on the court to stay legal proceedings where there is an arbitration agreement subject to the conditions specified in the section. The conditions thus specified are satisfied in the present case, but the section clearly contemplates that, even though there is an arbitration agreement and the requisite conditions specified by it are satisfied,

arguments.claim: Appellate court slow to interfere with trial court's discretion under s.34 unless unreasonable or capricious

anchor.surface_text: Where the discretion vested in the court under s. 34 has been exercised by the trial court the appellate court should be slow to interfere with the exercise of the said discretion.

arguments.claim: Under Art.136, interfere with discretion only if patently unreasonable, capricious or perverse

anchor.surface_text: In the present case there is one more fact which has to be borne in mind in dealing with the merits of the controversy before us. The appellant has come to this Court by special leave under Art. 136 in other words, the appellant is number entitled to challenge the correctness of the decision of the High Court as a matter of right.

arguments.claim: No justification to substitute our discretion for courts below given circumstances like embitterment, complexity, failed mediation

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances we do number think we would be justified in substituting our discretion for that of the courts below.

holdings.text: We would accordingly hold that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the present dispute between the parties was outside the scope of paragraph 4 of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly hold that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the present dispute between the parties was outside the scope of paragraph 4 of the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'interpretation or application of the contract' commonly cover disputes on construction, effect, and working out of contract terms in arbitration clauses; High Court's narrow view on 'application' erroneous.

holdings.text: The conditions thus specified are satisfied in the present case

anchor.surface_text: The conditions thus specified are satisfied in the present case, but the section clearly contemplates that, even though there is an arbitration agreement and the requisite conditions specified by it are satisfied,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitration agreement exists and dispute arises from contracts containing it; statutory prerequisites for s.34 application met.

holdings.text: Where the discretion vested in the court under s. 34 has been exercised by the trial court the appellate court should be slow to interfere with the exercise of the said discretion.

anchor.surface_text: Where the discretion vested in the court under s. 34 has been exercised by the trial court the appellate court should be slow to interfere with the exercise of the said discretion. In dealing with the matter raised before it at the appellate stage the appellate court would normally not be justified in interfering with the exercise of discretion under appeal solely on the ground that if it had considered the matter at the trial stage it would have come to a contrary conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellate interference justified only if trial court acted unreasonably, capriciously, ignored facts, or unjudicially; follows established principles from precedents like Charles Osenton Co. v. Johnston.

holdings.text: Under these circumstances we do not think we would be justified in substituting our discretion for that of the courts below.

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances we do not think we would be justified in substituting our discretion for that of the courts below. It may be that if we were trying the appellants application under s. 34 we might have come to a different conclusion and also that we may have hesitated to confirm the order of the trial court if we had been dealing with the matter as a court of first appeal but the matter has not come to us under Art. 136,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings on relevant factors (embittered relations, account complexity, limitation, failed mediation, appellant's change of stance) support refusal to stay; under Art.136, no patent unreasonableness warranting interference.

holdings.text: we can justly interfere with the concurrent exercise of the discretion by the courts below only if we feel that the said exercise of discretion is patently and manifestly unreasonable, capricious or perverse and that it may defeat the ends of justice.

anchor.surface_text: the matter has come to us under Art. 136, and so we can justly interfere with the concurrent exercise of the discretion by the courts below only if we feel that the said exercise of discretion is patently and manifestly unreasonable, capricious or perverse and that it may defeat the ends of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.136 special leave jurisdiction discretionary; limits review of lower courts' discretionary orders to cases of gross impropriety.

anchor.surface_text: Gardner v. Jay 1 that discretion, like other judicial discretion, must be exercised according to common sense and according to justice. In exercising its discretion under s. 34 the court should number refuse to stay the legal proceedings merely because one of the parties to the arbitration agreement is unwilling to go before an arbitrator and in effect wants to resile from the said agreement, number can stay be refused merely on the ground that the relations between the parties to the dispute have been embittered or that the proceedings before the arbitrator may cause unnecessary delay as a result of the said relations. It may number always be reasonable or proper to refuse to stay legal proceedings merely because some questions of law would arise in resolving the dispute between the parties. On the other hand, if fraud or dishonesty is alleged against a party it may be open to the party whose character is impeached to claim that it should be given an opportunity to vindicate its character in an open trial before the companyrt rather than before the domestic tribunal, and in a proper case the. companyrt may companysider that fact as relevant for deciding 1 1885 29 Ch. D 30 58, whether stay should be granted or number.

precedents.cited_proposition: discretion, like other judicial discretion, must be exercised according to common sense and according to justice

anchor.surface_text: Charles Osenton Co. v. Johnston 1 the law as to the reversal by a companyrt of appeal of an order made by a, judge below in the exercise of his discretion is well established, and any difficulty that arises is due only to the application of well settled principles in an individual case. In the present case there is one more fact which has to be borne in mind in dealing with the merits of the companytroversy before us. The appellant has companye to this Court by special leave under Art. 136 in other words, the appellant is number entitled to challenge the companyrectness of the decision of the High Court as a matter of right. It is only in the discretion of this Court that it can be permitted to dispute the companyrectness or the propriety of the decision of the High Court, and so in deciding whether or number this Court should interfere with the order under appeal it would be relevant for us to take into account the fact that the remedy sought for by the appellant is by an appeal which is a discretionary matter so far as this Court is companycerned. It is in the light of these principles that we must companysider whether or number the appellants companyplaint against the High Courts order can be upheld.

precedents.cited_proposition: the law as to the reversal by a court of appeal of an order made by a judge below in the exercise of his discretion is well established, and any difficulty that arises is due only to the application of well settled principles in an individual case

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to all the circumstances and facts of this case we are number disposed to hold that a case for our interference has been made out by the appellant.

outcome.relief_summary: No case for interference with the discretion exercised by the courts below refusing to stay the suit

edges.explanation: Holding that appellate court should be slow to interfere supports the broader concept of interference only if unreasonable or capricious

anchor.surface_text: Where the discretion vested in the court under s. 34 has been exercised by the trial court the appellate court should be slow to interfere with the exercise of the said discretion. In dealing with the matter raised before it at the appellate stage the appellate court would normally not be justified in interfering with the exercise of discretion under appeal solely on the ground that if it had considered the matter at the trial stage it would have come to a contrary conclusion.
Having regard to all the circumstances and facts of this case we are number disposed to hold that a case for our interference has been made out by the appellant.

Under these circumstances we do not think we would be justified in substituting our discretion for that of the courts below. It may be that if we were trying the appellants application under s. 34 we might have come to a different conclusion and also that we may have hesitated to confirm the order of the trial court if we had been dealing with the matter as a court of first appeal but the matter has not come to us under Art. 136,
